intro: Euklisia bakeri, commonly known as the Baker's mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees, primarily in tropical and subtropical regions. It has small, oval-shaped leaves that are usually arranged in a spiral pattern along the stem. The plant produces tiny, white or pale yellow flowers that are clustered in inflorescences, followed by small, fleshy berries that contain the seeds. Euklisia bakeri relies on its host for water and nutrients, but it can photosynthesize to some extent. Its unique growth habit and parasitic nature make it an interesting subject for ecological studies.
